questions.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
Which of the following is a photosynthetic pigment?
What is the main function of red blood cells?
Which organ is responsible for filtering blood in humans?
Which process involves the conversion of glucose into energy in cells?
What is the SI unit of force?
Who formulated the laws of motion?
What does the term 'velocity' refer to?
What is the speed of light in a vacuum?
What force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?
Who was the first President of the United States?
What year did World War II end?
The French Revolution began in which year?
What was the name of the ship that brought the Pilgrims to America in 1620?
Who was the famous leader of the Mongol Empire?
What is the chemical symbol for water?
Which element is known as the 'noble gas'?
Which acid is found in the stomach?
What is the pH level of pure water?
What is the most abundant element in the Earth's crust?
What is the square root of 64?
What is the value of Pi to two decimal places?
What is the result of 15 ÷ 3?
What is the perimeter of a rectangle with length 6 and width 4?
What is the formula for the area of a circle?
What does GDP stand for?
Which of these is considered a scarcity in economics?
What is inflation?
Which of the following is a type of market structure?
What is the main purpose of taxation?
Which of the following is a type of psychological disorder?
What is the main focus of cognitive psychology?
What part of the brain controls voluntary movement?
What does the term 'behaviorism' focus on in psychology?
Who is known as the father of psychoanalysis?
Who wrote the play 'Romeo and Juliet'?
What is the main theme of George Orwell's '1984'?
Which literary device is used in the phrase 'The wind whispered through the trees'?
Who is the author of 'The Great Gatsby'?
In which period was William Shakespeare most active?

courses.courseDescription: An introduction to the fundamental principles of biology, covering topics like cell biology, genetics, and ecology.
A basic introduction to the concepts of physics, including motion, energy, and forces.
An exploration of world history from ancient civilizations to modern times.
A foundational chemistry course covering the basics of chemical reactions, atomic structure, and the periodic table.
A basic course in mathematics, including algebra, calculus, and geometry.
An introductory course to economics, covering basic principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics.
A comprehensive introduction to the field of psychology, including behavior, cognition, and emotion.
A study of major works in English literature, from Shakespeare to modern writers.
